query: When managing pastureland for natural pest control, is it better to delay mowing/grazing or to use grazing instead of cutting?
relevant_summary:
One replicated study from Sweden found a decrease in ant diversity with delayed cutting, and one replicated, randomised, controlled study from the UK found no effect on spider and beetle diversity (727). In contrast, eight studies found that delaying mowing or grazing dates resulted in benefits to some or all plants, invertebrates or birds studied. These benefits included a greater abundance of some spiders and ground beetles (131). Three studies from the UK found no change in insect predator numbers and one replicated study from Sweden found mixed effects between different predator groups (727). One of two replicated, randomised, controlled studies from the UK and USA found more pest insects in late-cut plots and one found no effect (727). Two studies from Australia and the UK found grazing instead of cutting had mixed effects on natural enemies (885).

When grazing was used instead of cutting, one of five studies found more pests, and two studies found effects varied between pest groups and sampling dates. Two studies found no effect on pests (885). Six studies from Finland, the Netherlands, Sweden, Switzerland, and the UK found that delaying mowing or grazing dates on grassland had no clear effect on plant species richness, ground beetle communities, the abundance of some insects and spiders, or population trends of wading bird species (131).

query: What are the overall effects of altering pesticide application strategies to benefit natural enemies?
relevant_summary:
Altering pesticide application strategies can benefit natural enemies. One controlled study from the UK reported more natural enemies when insecticides were sprayed earlier in the growing season [723]. Two randomised, replicated, controlled trials from Australia and Denmark found more natural enemies when herbicide treatments were delayed, although one of the studies found some but not all natural enemy groups benefited [774]. One randomised, replicated, controlled study from Finland found that threshold-based spraying regimes increased numbers of natural enemies in two of three years [750].

When it comes to yield, one randomised, replicated, controlled study found lower yields and one study found no effect when herbicide treatments were delayed [774]. Four studies measured yields when altering the timing of insecticide use. Two studies found mixed effects and one study found no effect on yield when insecticides were applied early. One study found higher yields when insecticides were applied at times of suspected crop susceptibility [723]. Two of four randomised, replicated, controlled studies found similar yields under threshold-based and conventional spraying regimes. Two studies found mixed effects depending on site, year, pest stage/type or control treatment [750].

In terms of costs, one controlled study from the Philippines found higher profits and similar costs when insecticides were only applied at times of suspected crop susceptibility [723]. Nine studies found fewer pesticide applications were needed and three studies found or predicted lower production costs when using pesticides only when pests or crop damage reach threshold levels [750].

query: When planting non-crop vegetation to enhance natural pest control, what is the comparative evidence for planting new hedges versus plants that attract natural enemies with chemicals?
relevant_summary: When planting non-crop vegetation to enhance natural pest control, four studies found that growing non-crop plants that produce chemicals to attract natural enemies led to a higher number of natural enemies and a decrease in pest population or damage (724). One of these studies also found an increase in crop yield (724). In comparison, a literature review found that planting new hedges resulted in lower pest outbreaks (538). Two studies also found that newly planted hedges had a higher abundance and diversity of beetles or spiders than crop fields or field margins (538). However, one study found that planting new hedges had no effect on spiders in crops (752), and another found that the effect on natural enemies varied between crop types, hedge species, and years (752). The type of plant used in the hedge can also affect the arthropod diversity and natural enemy abundance (538, 752).

query: What are the potential negative impacts on crops when incorporating plant remains into the soil to control weeds?
relevant_summary: Two of three studies found that crop growth was inhibited by allelopathic plant remains (728). However, this effect could be minimized by changing the timing of the application (728). One study found negative effects on yield when amended plots were compared with weeded controls (728). The crops studied included beans, cotton, maize, rice, and wheat (728).

tools_called.args: {"query_string":"potential negative impacts on crops when incorporating plant remains into the soil to control weeds"}

  "key_messages": "Key Messages:
Biodiversity: One randomized, replicated experiment from Belgium found increased microbial biomass when crop remains and straw were added.
Compaction: One study from India found improved soil structure when straw was incorporated. One before-and-after trial from the UK found that incorporating straw residues by discing (reduced tillage) did not improve anaerobic soils (low oxygen levels) in compacted soils.
Erosion: Two randomized, replicated studies from Canada and India measured the effect of incorporating straw on erosion. One found straw addition reduced soil loss, and one found mixed effects depending on soil type.
Nutrient loss: Four replicated studies from Belgium, the UK and the USA (one also controlled, one also randomized, and two also controlled and randomized) reported higher soil nitrogen levels when compost or straw was applied, but mixed results when processed wastes were added. One also found reduced nitrate leaching when straw was incorporated. One replicated study from China and the Philippines found mixed results depending on site.
Soil organic carbon: Six studies from China, Denmark and India measured the effect of incorporating plant material into the soil. All (including one replicated, two randomized, replicated studies, one controlled, randomized, replicated studies and one controlled before-and-after site comparison) found higher carbon levels when plant material was added. One found higher carbon levels when straw was applied along with NPK fertilizers. One also found larger soil aggregates. One replicated study from China and the Philippines found mixed results depending on site.
Yield: One replicated trial from Denmark found higher barley yield when straw was incorporated. One trial from the Philippines found higher grain yields when crop remains were incorporated earlier in the season.
 
Soil types covered: clay, clay loam, fine loam, loam/sandy loam, loamy sand, sandy, sandy clay loam, sandy loam, sandy-silt, silt loam, silty, silty-clay."
}

query: What actions can be taken to control weeds on farmland without relying on herbicides?
relevant_summary: One method of weed control is to incorporate plant remains into the soil that produce weed-controlling chemicals. Some studies have found this can reduce weed growth, although the effects can vary and may not be long-lasting (728). The impact on crop growth, yield, and profit is also variable when compared to both weeded and unweeded control plots (728). In conservation areas, specific management regimes can reduce the abundance of pernicious weeds. Methods for controlling creeping thistle include cutting, the use of fungal pathogens, lenient grazing for long-term control, and the use of weevils to introduce systemic rust (123). Additionally, Hebridean sheep have been found to graze more purple moor grass than Swaledale sheep (123).

query: To provide refuge for natural enemies, what is the comparative evidence for creating beetle banks versus leaving part of a crop unharvested?
relevant_summary:
Leaving part of a crop unharvested was found in four studies to increase the number of predators in the unharvested area, and in three studies to increase predator numbers in the wider field (725). Two studies found that the ratio of predators to pests was higher in partially cut plots (725). One study found that creating beetle banks increased predator numbers in adjacent crops (729). Four studies found more invertebrate predators on beetle banks than in surrounding crops (729). Two studies found that beetle banks could lead to economic savings if pest numbers were kept below a spray threshold (729).

When leaving part of a crop unharvested, one study found an increase in predation, while two other studies found an increase in pest numbers in uncut areas (725). When creating beetle banks, one study found that beetle activity in fields was greater, but that this did not translate to increased pest predation (729). Another study found that any movement of predators from beetle banks to the crops was small or slow (729).

query: What are the potential economic outcomes of adopting organic farming or alley cropping systems?
relevant_summary: One study on organic farming found that net profit increased if produce received a premium, but otherwise profit decreased [717]. Another study on the same topic found a negative or no effect on profit [717]. In the context of alley cropping, one study found lower costs but also lower profit in alley cropped plots [718].

query: Which interventions are most effective for increasing pest parasitism rates?
relevant_summary: One replicated, controlled study from Australia found that leaving part of the crop or pasture unharvested or uncut led to an increase in predation and parasitism rates of pest eggs in the unharvested strips (725). Excluding ants that protect pests was found to increase parasitism of pests by natural enemies in one of two replicated, controlled studies from Japan and the USA, while the other study showed mixed results with greater parasitism at one site but no effect at another (886). A study in New Zealand on tomatoes found that using parasitism rates to inform spraying decisions resulted in acceptable levels of crop damage (726).

query: For pasture management in the UK, what is the comparative evidence on natural enemy abundance when delaying mowing versus using grazing instead of cutting?
relevant_summary: When considering pasture management in the UK, two studies, one of which was from the UK, found mixed results on natural enemy populations when grazing was used instead of cutting (885). One study from the UK that looked at the impact of delaying mowing found a decrease in the number of predatory spiders (727). However, three other studies from the UK reported no alteration in the number of insect predators (727). In addition, some studies have shown that delaying mowing can lead to an increase in the abundance of certain spiders and ground beetles, while other studies have found no discernible impact on the communities of ground beetles or the prevalence of some insects and spiders (131).

query: What is the evidence for the effectiveness of manipulating field structure by adding linear features like hedges, beetle banks, or alley cropping?
relevant_summary:
The use of alley cropping has been found to have mixed effects on parasitism, pests, and fungal infections, though a decrease in egg predation has been noted (718). In alley-cropped areas, there is an increase in wasps and spiders, but a decrease in ladybirds (718). While some studies have reported a higher number of pests and more crop damage, others have found the opposite or varied effects (718). Yields in these areas were either lower or similar to conventional fields, and despite lower costs, profits were also reduced (718).

Newly planted hedges can support a greater abundance and variety of beetles and spiders compared to crop fields (538). Furthermore, new hedges accommodate more ground beetles than older ones (538). A review of existing literature suggests that areas with new hedges experience fewer pest outbreaks (538). One study did not find any impact on spider populations in crops (752), but another indicated that the number of natural enemies in hedges could be greater than in the nearby crops, with this effect varying based on the type of crop and hedge (752). The type of plant used for the hedge also has an impact on the number of natural enemies (752). In terms of pests, one study revealed that the effects on nematodes differed between groups (752). Hedges also serve as corridors for the movement of invertebrates (538).

query: What actions are available to a farmer growing perennial crops to enhance natural enemy populations on the ground versus in the tree canopy?
relevant_summary:
Five studies compared natural and bare ground covers and their effects on natural enemies in fruit tree or vine canopies. Three of these studies found that the effects varied between different groups of natural enemies, while two found no difference [720]. Two additional studies compared natural to sown ground cover and found no effect on enemies in crop canopies [720].

When looking at natural enemies on the ground, five studies compared natural and bare ground covers. Two of these studies found more natural enemies in the natural ground cover, but in one study, the effects were only short-term for most natural enemy groups. Three other studies found mixed effects, with higher numbers of some natural enemy groups but not others [720]. Two studies compared natural and sown ground covers, with one study finding more natural enemies and the other finding no effect [720].

In relation to the tree canopy, one replicated, controlled study in Australia on cashew trees found that predatory ants occupied more trees when their colonies were kept isolated [773]. This same study also found lower pest damage and higher yields [773]. Furthermore, one of two replicated, controlled studies found greater parasitism of pests by natural enemies when ants were excluded from trees [886]. However, five other studies found that the effects of excluding ants on natural enemies in the tree canopy varied between species, sampling dates, sites, crop varieties, and ground cover types [886]. The crops studied included apple, grape, lemon, olive, pear, cashew, cherimoyas, cherry, grapefruit, orange, pecan, and satsuma mandarin [720, 773, 886].

tools_called.args: {"query_string":"actions for farmers growing perennial crops to enhance natural enemy populations on the ground versus in the tree canopy"}

query: What are the overall effects of weed management strategies that rely on plant competition or chemical properties?
relevant_summary:
Nine studies in Australia, Slovakia, the UK, and the USA that looked at the effects of planting species to compete with weeds discovered that this strategy reduced weed plant weight or ground cover (722). Five of these studies also discovered that competition reduced weed reproduction, survival, or both (722). One study in the USA on emergent non-woody vegetation planted in freshwater wetlands discovered that removing an invasive species with herbicide before sowing mixed grass and forb seeds increased the total biomass of sown species after 12 growing seasons, but that burning to remove the invasive species had no significant effect on sown species biomass (3332). Two studies in the United States looked at the effect of weeding to remove competitors on the survival of planted sedges and discovered that weeding had no significant effect on sedge survival in at least two of the three years (3332).

Six studies in Asia, Europe, and North America that looked at the effect of allelopathic plant remains on weeds discovered that three studies found a reduction in weed growth, while three found that the effects varied between years, weed groups, or the type of weeding method in controls (728). Two studies discovered that the decrease in weeds did not last more than a few days or weeks after the residue was incorporated (728). One study in the United Kingdom discovered that hydrogen peroxide did not control Crassula helmsii (1281). One study in Taiwan discovered that stopping the use of pesticides, along with managing the habitat, led to an increase in the population of Taipei frogs (832).

tools_called.return_val:
{
  "action_id": "3332",
  "action_title": "Remove vegetation that could compete with planted non-woody plants: freshwater wetlands",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Three studies evaluated the effects, on emergent non-woody vegetation planted in freshwater wetlands, of removing competing plants. All three studies were in the USA. Two studies used the same experimental wet basins but planted different species.

VEGETATION COMMUNITY
 
VEGETATION ABUNDANCE

Herb abundance (1 study): One replicated, randomized, paired, controlled study in wet meadows in the USA found removing an invasive species with herbicide before sowing mixed grass and forb seeds increased the total biomass of sown species after 1–2 growing seasons, but that burning to remove the invasive species had no significant effect on sown species biomass.
Individual species abundance (1 study): One replicated, paired, controlled study in wet basins in the USA found that the effect of weeding to remove competitors on lake sedge Carex lacustris biomass and density, in the three years after planting, depended on the year and water level.

VEGETATION STRUCTURE

Height (2 studies): Two replicated, paired, controlled studies in wet basins in the USA examined the effect of weeding to remove competitors on the height of planted sedges. One of the studies found that weeding had no significant effect on the height of planted tussock sedge Carex stricta in three of three years. The other study found that weeding reduced the average height of lake sedge Carex lacustris in the first year after planting, but had no significant effect in the following two years.

OTHER

Survival (2 studies): Two replicated, paired, controlled studies in wet basins in the USA examined the effect of weeding to remove competitors on the survival of planted sedges Carex spp. Both studies found that weeding had no significant effect on sedge survival in at least two of three years. One of the studies found that weeding affected tussock sedge Carex stricta survival in the second year after planting, but that the direction of the effect depended on plot elevation."
}

query: To attract natural enemies for pest control, what is the comparative evidence for using manufactured chemicals versus planting non-crop plants that produce attractive chemicals?
relevant_summary: Four studies on growing non-crop plants that produce attractive chemicals found a decrease in pest populations or damage, and three of these studies reported higher numbers of natural enemies (724). In contrast, the use of manufactured attractive chemicals showed more varied results. For manufactured chemicals, five out of thirteen studies found an increase in natural enemies, while eight studies found that positive effects varied between enemy groups, sites or study dates (754). Three of nine studies on manufactured chemicals found fewer pests, while two found more pests and four found no effect (754). One study on non-crop plants that produce attractive chemicals found an increase in crop yield (724), and one study on manufactured chemicals found an increase in wheat yields (754). Another related action of planting flowers to regulate pests also showed mixed results. While three replicated studies found greater pest reduction or higher proportions of parasitized pests (1400), one study found more pests on tomatoes next to planted flower strips, and another found more aphids in fields after flower strips were made available (1400). Two studies also found that some flower species were more attractive to natural enemies than others (1400).

tools_called.return_val:
{
  "action_id": "1400",
  "action_title": "Pest regulation: Plant flowers",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:
Pest regulation (3 studies): Three replicated studies from Italy and the USA found greater pest reduction or higher proportions of parasitized pests in fields and farms with planted flower strips.
Crop damage (2 studies): One replicated, randomized, controlled study from Italy found more damage by caterpillars, but not by aphids, in tomatoes next to planted flower strips, compared to tomatoes next to bare ground. One replicated, paired, controlled study from Italy found that planted flower strips had inconsistent effects on crop damage by pests.
Pest numbers (2 studies): One replicated, paired, controlled study from Italy found more pests on tomatoes next to planted flower strips, compared to tomatoes next to unplanted field margins. One replicated before-and-after study from the USA found more aphids in fields after flower strips were made available.
Natural enemy numbers (4 studies): Two replicated studies from the USA found more natural enemies in fields with planted flower strips, compared to fields without planted flower strips, in some comparisons. Two replicated, controlled studies from Italy found more natural enemies in planted flower strips than on bare ground, and one of these studies also found more species of natural enemies.
Implementation options (4 studies): Two replicated, controlled studies from the USA and Spain found that some flower species were more attractive to natural enemies than others. Two replicated, controlled studies from Italy found that planting more species of flowers, compared to fewer, had inconsistent effects on pests and pest species, but one of these found less crop damage next to flower strips with more species, compared to fewer, in some comparisons. This study also found more species of natural enemies in flower strips, over time, but did not find more individuals."
}

query: What are the documented effects on crop yield when altering the timing of agricultural practices like spraying or mowing for natural pest control?
relevant_summary:
Altering the timing of insecticide use has shown mixed effects on crop yield (723). Four studies were conducted, with two indicating varied outcomes, one reporting no change, and another finding higher yields when insecticides were applied during periods of anticipated crop vulnerability (723). When pesticides are used only after pest or crop damage reaches a certain threshold, two out of four studies found yields to be comparable to conventional spraying methods, while the other two noted mixed results depending on factors like location, year, and pest type (750). In contrast, a study on isolating beneficial ant colonies reported an increase in cashew yields (773). Delaying herbicide application resulted in lower yields in one study, and no effect in another (774). The use of push-pull cropping systems, which combine trap and repellent crops, was found to increase yields in four out of five studies (753).

The impact on pests and their natural enemies also varies. Earlier insecticide application was linked to a higher presence of natural enemies and, in two of four studies, a reduction in pests or disease-related damage (723). Threshold-based pesticide use was found to boost the populations of natural enemies in two out of three years, though these effects were sometimes short-lived (750). Isolating beneficial ant colonies led to more trees being occupied by these predatory ants and a decrease in pest-related damage (773). Delayed herbicide use was associated with an increase in natural enemies, but also more weeds (774). Push-pull systems were found to have more natural predators and increased parasitism of stem borer larvae (753).

query: What is the evidence from North America for using natural or ecological methods to control weeds?
relevant_summary: In North America, there are multiple ecological methods for weed control. Two out of four studies in Asia and North America showed that incorporating plant remains with weed-controlling chemicals into the soil reduced weed growth compared to unweeded controls (728). Two studies in the USA found that mixed pastures had fewer weeds than monoculture pastures (721). In the USA, one study on organic farming found mixed results on weed seed predation by natural enemies, while three other studies found more weeds in organic fields. However, one of these studies noted that the effect varied by crop and year, and another found no effect (717).

query: What is the summary of evidence on the economic outcomes, such as profit and costs, of implementing natural pest control methods?
relevant_summary: Two of three studies found that using threshold-based spraying regimes resulted in similar profits to conventional spraying regimes, with one study noting varied effects between sites and years (750). Additionally, two studies and a review indicated that push-pull cropping systems provided greater economic benefits (753). In terms of costs, nine studies found that threshold-based spraying led to fewer pesticide applications, and three studies reported or predicted lower production costs (750). One study on push-pull systems found higher production costs in the first year, but these costs were equal to or lower than conventional systems in the subsequent five years (753). Furthermore, a trial and a review suggest that beetle banks could lead to economic savings if they effectively prevent pests from reaching a spray threshold or causing a 5% loss in yield (729).

query: What are the observed effects of using chemical or plant-based attractants to enhance natural enemy populations?
relevant_summary: One review and two out of five studies found that attractive chemicals increased parasitism, while two studies showed varied effects based on chemicals, crops, or other factors (754). In terms of natural enemy populations, five of thirteen studies reported an increase, though eight studies indicated that these positive effects varied among different enemy groups and study conditions (754). The impact on pests was inconsistent, with three of nine studies observing fewer pests, two finding an increase, and four reporting no effect (754). For plant-based attractants, three out of four studies noted higher numbers of natural enemies in plots with plants that produce attractive chemicals (724). All four of these studies found a decrease in either pest population or crop damage, and one study reported an increase in crop yield (724).

query: When altering the timing of chemical applications for pest control, what are the comparative effects of delaying herbicide use versus changing insecticide timing?
relevant_summary:
Delaying herbicide treatments may lead to an increase in natural enemies, as supported by two controlled trials [774]. However, this action can also result in an increase in weeds, and its effects on insect pests are inconsistent, with one study noting an increase in some pest groups and another finding a decrease in certain contexts [774]. Yield outcomes from delaying herbicide use are also varied, with one study reporting lower yields and another finding no effect [774]. The crops studied in relation to this action were beet and oilseed [774].

In contrast, altering the timing of insecticide use has shown different effects. One study found that applying insecticides earlier in the season resulted in more natural enemies [723]. Early applications also led to fewer pests in two out of four studies, although two other studies showed no effect [723]. The impact on yield from changing insecticide timing is mixed, with two studies showing varied results, one finding no effect from early application, and another noting higher yields when applications were timed to coincide with crop susceptibility [723]. Furthermore, one study indicated that applying insecticides only at times of suspected crop susceptibility could lead to higher profits with similar costs [723]. The crops studied for this action included aubergine, barley, maize, pear, and stringbean [723].

Early applications also led to fewer pests in two out of four studies, although two other studies showed no effect [723]. Furthermore, one study indicated that applying insecticides only at times of suspected crop susceptibility could lead to higher profits with similar costs [723]. The crops studied for this action included aubergine, barley, maize, pear, and stringbean [723]."}

query: What are the documented financial impacts, in terms of profit and costs, of implementing various natural pest control strategies?
relevant_summary:
Several studies have documented the financial impacts of various natural pest control strategies, primarily focusing on crop yield. The use of crop rotations has been found to result in higher crop yields in some instances when compared to monocultures (1354). Similarly, adding compost to the soil has led to higher crop yields in some comparisons (1346), and in one case, fewer dead tomato plants (1392). The addition of pig slurry to the soil has also been associated with higher crop yields in some studies (1349).

The effects of other strategies have been more varied. For example, while planting flowers has been shown to increase crop yields in certain situations (1360) and lead to greater pest reduction (1400), it has also been linked to increased pest numbers and crop damage in other cases (1400), and smaller lettuces in one study (1360). The use of organic fertilizer has an inconsistent effect on yields, with some studies reporting higher, lower, or similar yields compared to inorganic fertilizers (1350).

Different tillage practices also show mixed results. Reduced tillage has been found to lead to higher, lower, or similar yields depending on the type of crop (1359). Similarly, studies on no-tillage systems have reported a range of outcomes, with yields being higher, lower, or the same as conventional tillage depending on the specific circumstances (1355, 1358).

The use of ground cover has also shown variable results. While allowing natural ground cover to regenerate can have mixed effects on pest populations (720), planting or maintaining ground cover in orchards and vineyards has been found to decrease grape and avocado yields in some studies, while increasing chestnut and mushroom yields in others (1352). Furthermore, growing cover crops in arable fields has been found to result in lower, inconsistent, or no difference in cash crop yields in a number of studies (1351).

{
  "action_id": "1400",
  "action_title": "Pest regulation: Plant flowers",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:
Pest regulation (3 studies): Three replicated studies from Italy and the USA found greater pest reduction or higher proportions of parasitized pests in fields and farms with planted flower strips.
Crop damage (2 studies): One replicated, randomized, controlled study from Italy found more damage by caterpillars, but not by aphids, in tomatoes next to planted flower strips, compared to tomatoes next to bare ground. One replicated, paired, controlled study from Italy found that planted flower strips had inconsistent effects on crop damage by pests.
Pest numbers (2 studies): One replicated, paired, controlled study from Italy found more pests on tomatoes next to planted flower strips, compared to tomatoes next to unplanted field margins. One replicated before-and-after study from the USA found more aphids in fields after flower strips were made available.
Natural enemy numbers (4 studies): Two replicated studies from the USA found more natural enemies in fields with planted flower strips, compared to fields without planted flower strips, in some comparisons. Two replicated, controlled studies from Italy found more natural enemies in planted flower strips than on bare ground, and one of these studies also found more species of natural enemies.
Implementation options (4 studies): Two replicated, controlled studies from the USA and Spain found that some flower species were more attractive to natural enemies than others. Two replicated, controlled studies from Italy found that planting more species of flowers, compared to fewer, had inconsistent effects on pests and pest species, but one of these found less crop damage next to flower strips with more species, compared to fewer, in some comparisons. This study also found more species of natural enemies in flower strips, over time, but did not find more individuals."
}

{
  "action_id": "1392",
  "action_title": "Pest regulation: Add compost to the soil",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:
Pest regulation (2 studies): Of two replicated, randomized, controlled studies from the USA and an unspecified Mediterranean country, one study found less disease in crops grown in soils with added compost, compared to soils without it, in some comparisons, but one study found no differences in most crop diseases. One replicated, controlled study from the USA found similar amounts of Escherichia coli bacteria in plots with or without added compost. This study also found that similar percentages of pests were consumed by natural enemies in plots with or without added compost.
Crop damage (1 study): One replicated, randomized, controlled study found fewer dead tomato plants in soil with added compost, compared to soil without added compost, in some comparisons.
Ratio of natural enemies to pests (1 study): One replicated, controlled study from the USA found similar ratios of natural enemies to pests (mostly aphids) in plots with or without added compost.
Pest numbers (1 study): One replicated, controlled study from the USA found similar pest numbers in plots with or without added compost.
Natural enemy numbers (0 studies)"
}

Crop yield (11 studies)

Food crops (10 studies): Four replicated studies (three controlled, two randomized; one site comparison) from Italy and Spain found higher yields in plots with organic fertilizer, compared to inorganic fertilizer, in some comparisons. Three replicated, randomized, controlled studies from Spain and the USA found lower yields in plots with organic fertilizer, compared to inorganic fertilizer, in some or all comparisons. Three replicated, randomized, controlled studies from Greece and Spain found similar yields in plots with organic or inorganic fertilizer.
Forage crops (1 study): One replicated, randomized, controlled study from Spain found higher alfalfa yields in plots with organic fertilizer, compared to inorganic, in one of two comparisons.

Crop quality (0 studies)"
}

{

One replicated, randomized, controlled study from Italy found higher crop yields in tomatoes next to planted flower strips, compared to tomatoes next to bare ground, in some comparisons.
Crop quality (0 studies)


Implementation options (3 studies): One replicated, randomized, controlled study from the USA found smaller lettuces in fields planted with flowers, in five out of six configurations. One replicated, controlled study from Spain found higher coriander yields next to field margins planted with more flower species, compared to fewer flower species. One replicated, randomized, controlled study from Italy found lower crop yields in tomatoes next to field margins planted with more flower species, compared to fewer flower species, in some comparisons."

{
  "action_id": "1359",
  "action_title": "Crop production: Use reduced tillage in arable fields",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:
Crop yield (25 studies)

Cereals (16 studies): Nine replicated, controlled studies from Egypt, France, Spain, and Turkey found higher cereal yields in plots with reduced tillage, compared to conventional tillage, in some or all comparisons. Three of these studies also found lower cereal yields in plots with reduced tillage, compared to conventional tillage, in some comparisons. Three replicated, randomized, controlled studies from Lebanon and Spain found lower cereal yields in plots with reduced tillage, compared to conventional tillage. Four replicated, controlled studies from Italy, Spain, and the USA found similar cereal yields in plots with reduced tillage or conventional tillage, in all comparisons. One replicated, randomized, controlled study from Spain found that crops failed in plots with conventional tillage, but not in plots with reduced tillage, in one of three comparisons.
Fruits and vegetables (7 studies): Five replicated, randomized, controlled studies from Italy and the USA found higher fruit or vegetable yields in plots with reduced tillage, compared to conventional tillage, in some comparisons. Two of these studies also found lower fruit or vegetable yields in plots with reduced tillage, compared to conventional tillage, in some comparisons. Two replicated, controlled studies from Italy and the USA found similar fruit yields in plots with reduced tillage or conventional tillage, in all comparisons. All fruit or vegetable plots were irrigated, in contrast to most cereal or legume plots.
Legumes (3 studies): One replicated, randomized, controlled study from Spain found lower legume yields in plots with reduced tillage, compared to conventional tillage, in one of four comparisons. Two replicated, controlled studies from Italy and Lebanon found similar legume yields in plots with reduced tillage or conventional tillage, in all comparisons. No studies found higher legume yields in plots with reduced tillage, compared to conventional tillage.
Oilseeds (1 study): One replicated, randomized, controlled study from Spain found higher rapeseed yields in plots with reduced tillage, compared to conventional tillage.
Crop residues (6 studies): Two replicated, randomized, controlled studies from Lebanon and Spain found lower straw yields in plots with reduced tillage, compared to conventional tillage, in some comparisons. One replicated, randomized, controlled study from Spain found higher straw yields in plots with reduced tillage, compared to conventional tillage, in some comparisons. Two replicated, controlled studies from Italy and Spain found similar straw yields in plots with reduced tillage or conventional tillage, in all comparisons. One replicated, randomized, controlled study from the USA found higher cover crop biomass in plots with reduced tillage, compared to conventional tillage.

Crop quality (7 studies): One replicated, randomized, controlled study from Spain found that sunflower seeds had more oil, more monounsaturated fatty acid, and less polyunsaturated fatty acid in plots with reduced tillage, compared to conventional tillage. One replicated, controlled study from Italy found that wheat had a lower protein content in plots with reduced tillage, compared to conventional tillage. Two replicated, controlled studies from Italy and Turkey found similar seed weights in plots with reduced tillage, compared to conventional tillage. One replicated, randomized, controlled study from the USA found that lettuce or broccoli plants were larger in plots with reduced tillage, compared to conventional tillage, in some comparisons, but they were smaller in other comparisons.
Implementation options (2 studies): One replicated, randomized, controlled study from Egypt found higher wheat yields in plots that were tilled at slower speeds. One replicated, randomized, controlled study from Turkey found higher wheat yields, but lower vetch yields, in plots with one type of reduced tillage (rototilling and disking), compared to another type (double disking)."
}

  "key_messages": "Key Messages:
Crop yield (15 studies)

Cereals (7 studies): Three replicated, randomized, controlled studies from Spain found higher cereal yields in plots with no tillage, compared to reduced tillage. One of these studies also found lower cereal yields in some comparisons. One replicated, randomized, controlled study from Spain found lower cereal yields in plots with no tillage, compared to reduced tillage, in some comparisons. Three replicated, randomized, controlled studies from Australia, Lebanon, and Spain found similar cereal yields in plots with no tillage or reduced tillage, in all comparisons. 
Fruits and vegetables (3 studies): Three replicated, randomized, controlled studies from Italy found lower fruit or vegetable yields in plots with no tillage, compared to reduced tillage, in some comparisons. Two of these studies also found higher yields, in some comparisons.

{
  "action_id": "1352",
  "action_title": "Crop production: Plant or maintain ground cover in orchards or vineyards",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:
Crop yield (11 studies)

Grapes (8 studies): Two replicated, randomized, controlled studies from France and the USA found lower grape 	yields in plots that were seeded with grass between the vine rows, compared to plots with bare soil between the vine 	rows, in some or all comparisons. Six replicated, randomized, controlled studies from Italy, 	Portugal, Spain, and the USA found similar grape yields in plots with or without ground cover between the 	vine rows.
Other crops (3 studies): Two replicated, randomized, controlled studies from Portugal found higher chestnut yields in plots with resident vegetation, compared to plots without ground cover, but found no difference in chestnut yields between plots with seeded cover crops and plots without ground cover. One of these studies also found higher mushroom yields in plots with resident vegetation, compared to plots without ground cover. One replicated, randomized, controlled study from Chile found lower avocado yields in plots that were seeded with grasses and legumes, compared to plots with bare soil.

 
Crop quality (8 studies)

Grapes (6 studies): Five replicated, randomized, controlled studies from Italy, Portugal, and the USA found similar sugar contents in grapes with or without ground cover between the vine rows. Three of these studies found similar pH levels, and two of these studies found no differences in titratable acidity, but two of these studies found lower titratable acidity in grapes with ground cover between the vine rows. One replicated, randomized, controlled study from the USA found heavier grapes with ground cover between the vine rows, but two replicated, randomized, controlled studies from Italy and Spain did not. Two replicated, randomized, controlled studies from Portugal and Spain found other differences in grape quality with ground cover between the vine rows.
Other crops (2 studies): One replicated, randomized, controlled study from Portugal found larger chestnuts in plots with ground cover, compared to plots without ground cover. One replicated, randomized, controlled study from Chile found no difference in avocado quality in plots with or without ground cover.

 
Implementation options (6 studies)

Ground cover (5 studies)          

Grapes (3 studies): One replicated, randomized, controlled study from the USA found similar grape yields in plots with different types of ground cover. However, this study found lighter-weight clusters of grapes in plots with seeded cover crops, compared to resident vegetation, in one of three years, and found inconsistent differences in cluster weights between plots with different types of seeded cover crops. Two replicated, randomized, controlled studies from Spain and the USA found other differences in grape quality between plots with different types of ground cover.
Other crops (2 studies): Two replicated, randomized, controlled studies from Portugal found lower chestnut yields in plots with seeded cover crops, compared to resident vegetation. One of these studies also found smaller chestnuts and lower mushroom yields.


Tillage (2 studies): One replicated, randomized, controlled study from the USA found higher grape yields, and heavier grape clusters, in plots without tillage between the vine rows, in one of six comparisons. Another replicated, randomized, controlled study from the USA found similar grape yields, with or without tillage between the vine rows."
}

{
  "action_id": "1355",
  "action_title": "Crop production: Use no tillage in arable fields",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:
Crop yield (23 studies)

Crops (22 studies): Eight replicated, controlled studies (seven randomized) from Italy and Spain found higher crop yields in plots with no tillage, compared to conventional tillage, in some or all comparisons. Seven replicated, controlled studies (six randomized) from Italy, Lebanon, Spain, and the USA found lower crop yields in plots with no tillage, compared to conventional tillage, in some or all comparisons. Four replicated, randomized controlled studies from Italy and Spain found inconsistent differences in crop yields (sometimes higher with no tillage, sometimes lower). Three replicated, controlled studies (two randomized) from Italy, Portugal, and Spain found similar crop yields in plots with or without tillage.
Crop residues (5 studies): Two replicated, randomized, controlled studies from Lebanon and Spain found higher straw yields in plots with no tillage, compared to conventional tillage, in some comparisons. One replicated, randomized, controlled study from Spain found inconsistent straw yields (sometimes higher with no tillage, sometimes lower). Two replicated, controlled studies (one randomized) from Italy and Spain found similar straw yields in plots with or without tillage.

Crop quality (6 studies): One replicated, controlled study from Italy found less protein in wheat grains from plots with no tillage, compared to conventional tillage. One replicated, randomized, controlled study from Spain found heavier cereal grains in plots with no tillage, compared to conventional tillage. Two replicated, randomized, controlled studies from Spain found other differences in crop quality, but two replicated, controlled studies from Italy and the USA did not."
}

tools_called.args:
{"action_ids":["720","1400","1392","1354","1350","1346","1360","1359","1358","1352","1349","1355","1351"],"query":"What are the documented financial impacts, in terms of profit and costs, of implementing various natural pest control strategies?","summary":"Several studies have documented the financial impacts of various natural pest control strategies, primarily focusing on crop yield. The use of crop rotations has been found to result in higher crop yields in some instances when compared to monocultures (1354). Similarly, adding compost to the soil has led to higher crop yields in some comparisons (1346), and in one case, fewer dead tomato plants (1392). The addition of pig slurry to the soil has also been associated with higher crop yields in some studies (1349).

The effects of other strategies have been more varied. For example, while planting flowers has been shown to increase crop yields in certain situations (1360) and lead to greater pest reduction (1400), it has also been linked to increased pest numbers and crop damage in other cases (1400), and smaller lettuces in one study (1360). The use of organic fertilizer has an inconsistent effect on yields, with some studies reporting higher, lower, or similar yields compared to inorganic fertilizers (1350).

Different tillage practices also show mixed results. Reduced tillage has been found to lead to higher, lower, or similar yields depending on the type of crop (1359). Similarly, studies on no-tillage systems have reported a range of outcomes, with yields being higher, lower, or the same as conventional tillage depending on the specific circumstances (1355, 1358).

The use of ground cover has also shown variable results. While allowing natural ground cover to regenerate can have mixed effects on pest populations (720), planting or maintaining ground cover in orchards and vineyards has been found to decrease grape and avocado yields in some studies, while increasing chestnut and mushroom yields in others (1352). Furthermore, growing cover crops in arable fields has been found to result in lower, inconsistent, or no difference in cash crop yields in a number of studies (1351)."}

query: What actions are available to control weeds specifically in pasture or grassland systems?
relevant_summary: Utilizing mixed pasture instead of monoculture has been found to reduce weeds (721). In conservation areas, the application of grass-specific herbicides has been shown to decrease grass diversity while promoting the growth of broadleaved plants (123). Other methods for controlling creeping thistle include cutting, introducing fungal pathogens, and implementing lenient grazing strategies (123). Additionally, weevils can be employed to infect creeping thistle with systemic rust (123). In prairie restoration efforts, methods such as seeding with native species, mowing, and weeding or applying herbicides have been used (3943). It was also observed that Hebridean sheep tended to graze more on purple moor grass compared to Swaledale sheep (123).

tools_called.return_val:
{
  "action_id": "3943",
  "action_title": "Restore or create grassland/savannas",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Six studies evaluated the effects on butterflies and moths of restoring or creating grassland or savanna. Three studies were in the USA, two were in the UK, and one was in Italy.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (1 STUDY)

Richness/diversity (1 study): One replicated, paired, site comparison study in Italy found that created semi-natural grasslands had a greater diversity of butterflies than adjacent conifer forests, but a lower diversity than species-rich pastures.

POPULATION RESPONSE (4 STUDIES)

Abundance (4 studies): Two site comparison studies (including one replicated, paired study) in Italy and the USA found that created semi-natural grasslands and restored grasslands and oak barrens had a higher abundance of butterflies and regal fritillaries than adjacent conifer forests, species-rich pastures or unmanaged or remnant prairies. One site comparison study in the USA found that prairies restored 5–10 years ago by seeding with native species, mowing, and weeding or applying herbicide, had a greater abundance of Fender’s blue eggs than a prairie restored 1–2 years ago, and a similar abundance to remnant prairies. One study in the USA reported that restored prairie supported a translocated population of regal fritillaries for at least three years after restoration.

BEHAVIOUR (3 STUDIES)

Use (2 studies): One of two replicated, before-and-after studies in the UK reported that following grassland restoration the area occupied by small pearl-bordered fritilliaries increased. The other study reported that following grassland restoration the number of marsh fritillary populations at each site remained the same or increased.
Behaviour change (1 study): One site comparison study in the USA found that Fender’s blue butterflies spent a similar proportion of time laying eggs in prairies restored 5–10 years ago by seeding with nectar species, mowing, and weeding or applying herbicide, and in remnant prairies."
}
